headline: YF Invest, Disney earnings, Fed commentary: What to Watch
summary: Market Domination Overtime host Josh Lipton previews several of the biggest stories to come tomorrow, Thursday, November 13, including: Yahoo Finance's Invest conference kicks off tomorrow, Thursday, November 13, at 8:00 A.M. Tune in for a day filled with high-profile interviews and panel discussions. Earnings results from companies like Disney (DIS) and Applied Materials (AMAT). And, a slew of commentary from Federal Reserve regional central bank presidents. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: Review & Preview: Open for Business
summary: Investors today were once again cheering the imminent end of the shutdown.  The House of Representatives is set to pass a government funding bill tonight that will end the record-breaking 43-day shutdown, with a final vote expect tonight, perhaps just as this newsletter is hitting your inboxes.

headline: Disney: Fiscal Q4 Earnings Snapshot

content.title: Disney: Fiscal Q4 Earnings Snapshot
content.summary: BURBANK, Calif. AP) — The Walt Disney Co. (DIS) on Thursday reported fiscal fourth-quarter profit of $1.31 billion. On a per-share basis, the Burbank, California-based company said it had profit of 73 cents.

headline: Disney revenue hit by cable weakness, overshadowing gains in parks and streaming
summary: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) -Walt Disney missed Wall Street estimates for quarterly revenue on Thursday as ongoing weakness in its cable TV unit overshadowed solid growth in streaming and theme parks, ​sending its shares down more than 3.9% in premarket trading.  Profit rose in Disney's theme parks unit, partially from an expansion of the U.S. cruise ship business and growth at Disneyland Paris.  Disney said it added 12.5 million subscribers to Disney+ and Hulu during the quarter, reaching a total of 196 million.

content.title: Disney revenue hit by cable weakness, overshadowing gains in parks and streaming
content.summary: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) -Walt Disney missed Wall Street estimates for quarterly revenue on Thursday as ongoing weakness in its cable TV unit overshadowed solid growth in streaming and theme parks, ​sending its shares down more than 3.9% in premarket trading.  Profit rose in Disney's theme parks unit, partially from an expansion of the U.S. cruise ship business and growth at Disneyland Paris.  Disney said it added 12.5 million subscribers to Disney+ and Hulu during the quarter, reaching a total of 196 million.

headline: Disney (NYSE:DIS) Misses Q3 CY2025 Revenue Estimates
summary: Global entertainment and media company Disney (NYSE:DIS) fell short of the markets revenue expectations in Q3 CY2025, with sales flat year on year at $22.46 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.11 per share was 8.4% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Disney warns of potentially long distribution dispute with YouTube TV, shares fall
summary: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) -Walt Disney signaled on Thursday it was girding for a potentially prolonged fight with YouTube TV over distribution of its television  channels, worrying investors about the outlook for its already ​declining TV business and pushing its shares down 6.6%.  On a post-earnings call, Chief Financial Officer Hugh Johnston told analysts Disney has "built a hedge" into its forecasts assuming the negotiations could drag on.  NBCUniversal also had a similar dispute with YouTube TV earlier this year.

content.title: Disney warns of potentially long distribution dispute with YouTube TV, shares fall
content.summary: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) -Walt Disney signaled on Thursday it was girding for a potentially prolonged fight with YouTube TV over distribution of its television  channels, worrying investors about the outlook for its already ​declining TV business and pushing its shares down 6.6%.  On a post-earnings call, Chief Financial Officer Hugh Johnston told analysts Disney has "built a hedge" into its forecasts assuming the negotiations could drag on.  NBCUniversal also had a similar dispute with YouTube TV earlier this year.

headline: Disney Posts Roughly Flat Quarterly Revenue as TV Declines Continue
summary: Disney’s  TV networks and movie business struggled in the September quarter, while its parks and streaming businesses gained ground, a mixed result for the entertainment giant.  Revenue for Disney was $22.46 billion in the quarter, which was lower than Wall Street expectations, while companywide segment operating income fell 5% to $3.48 billion, the company said Thursday.  Disney shares fell about 6% in premarket trading.

content.title: Disney Posts Roughly Flat Quarterly Revenue as TV Declines Continue
content.summary: Disney’s  TV networks and movie business struggled in the September quarter, while its parks and streaming businesses gained ground, a mixed result for the entertainment giant.  Revenue for Disney was $22.46 billion in the quarter, which was lower than Wall Street expectations, while companywide segment operating income fell 5% to $3.48 billion, the company said Thursday.  Disney shares fell about 6% in premarket trading.

headline: Streaming and parks shine for Disney in Q4, but weakening in cable and at the box office
summary: Disney's fourth-quarter performance was mixed with a weaker performance from cable and the box office somewhat offset by strength in its streaming business and theme parks.  Disney is still trying to work out a new licensing deal with YouTube after its content went dark on YouTube TV two weeks ago, leaving subscribers of the Google-owned livestreaming platform without access to major networks like ESPN during the college football season.  The Walt Disney Co. earned $1.31 billion, or 73 cents per share, for the three months ended Sept. 25.

content.title: Streaming and parks shine for Disney in Q4, but weakening in cable and at the box office
content.summary: Disney's fourth-quarter performance was mixed with a weaker performance from cable and the box office somewhat offset by strength in its streaming business and theme parks.  Disney is still trying to work out a new licensing deal with YouTube after its content went dark on YouTube TV two weeks ago, leaving subscribers of the Google-owned livestreaming platform without access to major networks like ESPN during the college football season.  The Walt Disney Co. earned $1.31 billion, or 73 cents per share, for the three months ended Sept. 25.

headline: Disney CFO Says Streaming Business Is Expected to Grow by Double Digits
summary: Disney says sales fell short of Wall Street expectations in the fourth quarter but earnings beat estimates. CFO Hugh Johnston says the company is investing heavily in streaming, films and TV. He says a strong slate of movies including Zootopia 2 and Avatar: Fire and Ash, will help the streaming business keep growing. He speaks on Bloomberg Open Interest.

content.description: Disney says sales fell short of Wall Street expectations in the fourth quarter but earnings beat estimates. CFO Hugh Johnston says the company is investing heavily in streaming, films and TV. He says a strong slate of movies including Zootopia 2 and Avatar: Fire and Ash, will help the streaming business keep growing. He speaks on Bloomberg Open Interest.

headline: Disney’s CEO Sequel Isn’t Having a Hollywood Ending
summary: Walt Disney's earnings this morning marked three years since Bob Iger returned for what was supposed to be a two-year encore as chief executive.  This time around, Disney shares have trailed the S&P 500 by nearly 50 percentage points and those of streaming rival Netflix by more than 250.  As is typical for a boomerang CEO, the market’s initial reaction was hopeful, with a 5% jump in Disney’s stock after the announcement.

content.title: Disney’s CEO Sequel Isn’t Having a Hollywood Ending
content.summary: Walt Disney's earnings this morning marked three years since Bob Iger returned for what was supposed to be a two-year encore as chief executive.  This time around, Disney shares have trailed the S&P 500 by nearly 50 percentage points and those of streaming rival Netflix by more than 250.  As is typical for a boomerang CEO, the market’s initial reaction was hopeful, with a 5% jump in Disney’s stock after the announcement.
